channel.title: JaneBytes Cybersecurity Feed
channel.description: Summarized articles from top cybersecurity sources.

item.title: Researchers Reveal How Hacktivist Groups Gain Attention and Choose Their Targets
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have released findings on the operational dynamics of hacktivist organizations, revealing sophisticated attention-seeking behaviors and strategic target selection methodologies. The study highlights hacktivists' calculated targeting strategies, self-promotion mechanisms, and use of psychological warfare approaches to amplify their perceived influence. It also notes the commercialization trend within the hacktivist community and the increasing focus on capability development, leading to a more complex threat landscape.

item.title: UNG0002 Actors Weaponize LNK Files via ClickFix Fake CAPTCHA Pages
item.description: The article reports on a sophisticated espionage group known as UNG0002 (Unknown Group 0002) that has been conducting persistent campaigns across multiple Asian jurisdictions since May 2024. The group uses social engineering techniques, advanced malware deployment methods, and custom-developed implants to target organizations in China, Hong Kong, and Pakistan.

item.title: UK’s Co-op Retailer Hit by Cyberattack, 6.5 Million Members’ Data Exposed
item.description: The UK's Co-op retailer suffered a significant cyberattack in April 2024, resulting in the theft of personal data from all 6.5 million members. While no financial information was compromised, hackers accessed names, addresses, and contact information. The breach highlights the ongoing cybersecurity challenges facing major retailers and the importance of robust preventive measures.

item.title: Europol Disrupts NoName057(16) Hacktivist Group Linked to DDoS Attacks Against Ukraine
item.description: The article discusses an international operation led by Europol to disrupt the infrastructure of a pro-Russian hacktivist group called NoName057(16) that has been linked to DDoS attacks against Ukraine and its allies. The joint effort resulted in the dismantling of the group's central server infrastructure, arrests, searches, and issuance of arrest warrants.

item.title: NVIDIA Container Toolkit Vulnerability Allows Privileged Code Execution by Attackers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: NVIDIA Container Toolkit and GPU Operator; CVE(s): CVE-2025-23266, CVE-2025-23267; Summary: The NVIDIA Container Toolkit and GPU Operator contain two critical vulnerabilities that allow attackers to execute arbitrary code with elevated privileges. The first vulnerability (CVE-2025-23266) has a CVSS score of 9.0, while the second (CVE-2025-23267) has a score of 8.5. These flaws enable privilege escalation, data tampering, information disclosure, and denial-of-service attacks in containerized environments.

item.title: 1-Click Oracle Cloud Code Editor RCE Flaw Allows Malicious File Upload to Shell
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Code Editor; CVE(s): None; Summary: A critical Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure's Code Editor enabled attackers to silently hijack victim Cloud Shell environments through a single malicious link, allowing for potential lateral movement across OCI services and compromise of integrated developer tools. The vulnerability stemmed from a Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) weakness in the file upload mechanism, which was remediated by implementing additional CSRF protections requiring a custom HTTP header.

item.title: CTEM vs ASM vs Vulnerability Management: What Security Leaders Need to Know in 2025
item.description: The article discusses the importance of implementing Continuous Threat Exposure Management (CTEM) programs, which complement Vulnerability Management (VM) and Attack Surface Management (ASM). CTEM provides a systematic approach to discover, prioritize, validate, and respond to security exposures. The article also highlights the benefits of integrating VM, ASM, and penetration testing solutions into a unified interface to support a holistic CTEM program.

item.title: Iranian Threat Actors Use AI-Generated Emails to Target Cybersecurity Researchers and Academics
item.description: This article discusses Iranian state-backed Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) groups and their hacktivist allies' increased cyber operations following Israeli and American strikes on Iranian nuclear and military facilities. The article highlights the groups' tactics, including espionage, disruption, and psychological warfare, as well as their use of AI-enhanced phishing operations and industrial control system scanning.

item.title: MaaS operation using Emmenhtal and Amadey linked to threats against Ukrainian entities
item.description: A Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) operation, dubbed "Amadey," has been identified by Cisco Talos. The operation uses fake GitHub accounts to host payloads and tools, allowing operators to deliver various malware families to infected hosts. This MaaS operation overlaps with a previous SmokeLoader phishing campaign targeting Ukrainian entities.

item.title: Hackers Use DNS Queries to Evade Defenses and Exfiltrate Data
item.description: DNS tunneling is a technique used by cybercriminals to bypass corporate security measures and steal sensitive data by encoding data within DNS queries and responses. The attack process begins when threat actors gain control of a domain name's authoritative name server, allowing them to conduct command-and-control (C2) operations and data exfiltration while remaining largely undetected.

item.title: Threat Actors Deploy 28+ Malicious Packages to Spread Protestware Scripts
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Socket's Threat Research Team; CVE(s): None; Summary: A network of at least 28 malicious packages, including protestware scripts, was discovered in the npm supply chain. The protestware disrupts user interface interactions by disabling mouse events and initiating playback of the Ukrainian national anthem, affecting Russian-language users on specific domains. The vulnerability highlights the risks of code reuse in open-source repositories, where undisclosed payloads can cascade through dependencies, amplifying potential impacts on downstream applications.

item.title: PyPI Blocks Inbox.ru Domains After 1,500+ Fake Package Uploads
item.description: PyPI blocked the inbox.ru email domain after a campaign created over 250 fraudulent accounts and uploaded more than 1,500 empty projects, causing confusion among end-users and straining resources. The incident highlights the delegated security model of PyPI's registration process and emphasizes the importance of user vigilance and advanced detection mechanisms to prevent future incursions.

item.title: Critical SharePoint RCE Vulnerability Exploited via Malicious XML in Web Part
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft SharePoint; CVE(s): None; Summary: A severe remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in Microsoft SharePoint allows attackers to execute arbitrary code through malicious XML content embedded within web parts. The vulnerability originates from the deserialization process of web part properties and can be exploited through multiple endpoints, including the _/vti_bin/webpartpages.asmx service using the ConvertWebPartFormat SOAP action.

item.title: Hackers Actively Exploited CitrixBleed 2 Flaw Ahead of PoC Disclosure
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Citrix; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5777; Summary: The CitrixBleed 2 vulnerability was exploited by threat actors nearly two weeks before a public proof-of-concept was released, highlighting the sophistication of modern attack campaigns. Initial exploitation began on June 23, followed by the public release of a proof-of-concept on July 4, and GreyNoise's subsequent creation of a tracking tag on July 7. The vulnerability represents a significant security risk for organizations running Citrix NetScaler appliances.

item.title: Cisco Unified Intelligence Center Flaw Lets Remote Attackers Upload Arbitrary Files
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Unified Intelligence Center; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20274; Summary: A critical vulnerability in Cisco's Unified Intelligence Center allows authenticated remote attackers to upload arbitrary files, potentially enabling complete system compromise through privilege escalation to root access. The flaw stems from improper file validation and can be exploited by users with Report Designer role privileges, allowing for the execution of arbitrary commands on the underlying operating system.

item.title: Weaponizing SVG: How Threat Actors Embed Malicious JavaScript in Vector Files
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: Researchers have identified an emerging attack campaign using Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) files to deliver JavaScript-based redirect attacks. The technique exploits the inherent trust in image formats, allowing malicious actors to embed obfuscated JavaScript within SVG files that execute automatically when opened in web browsers.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Target Taiwan's Semiconductor Sector with Cobalt Strike, Custom Backdoors
item.description: The article reports on spear-phishing campaigns conducted by three Chinese state-sponsored threat actors targeting the Taiwanese semiconductor industry. The campaigns involve phishing emails with malicious payloads, including Cobalt Strike or a custom backdoor, and DLL side-loading to spawn reverse shells and establish command-and-control connections.

item.title: 0-Day RCE Flaw in SonicWall SMA Devices Exploited to Launch OVERSTEP Ransomware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall; CVE(s): CVE-2024-38475, None; Summary: Threat actors are exploiting previously stolen credentials and a new rootkit called OVERSTEP to target end-of-life SonicWall Secure Mobile Access (SMA) 100 series appliances. The campaign represents a significant escalation in attacks against network infrastructure devices, as the threat actors are successfully compromising appliances even after organizations have applied the latest security updates.

item.title: Cloudflare Confirms BGP Hijack Behind 1.1.1.1 DNS Disruption
item.description: A global outage of Cloudflare's 1.1.1.1 DNS resolver service was caused by an internal configuration error rather than an external attack. The incident affected millions of users worldwide and coincided with an unrelated BGP hijack, which complicated the situation.

item.title: Europol Takes Down NoName057(16)’s Global Network of Over 100 Servers
item.description: Europol and Eurojust conducted Operation Eastwood to dismantle the NoName057(16) hacktivist collective's global infrastructure of over 100 servers worldwide. The operation resulted in two arrests, seven international arrest warrants, 24 house searches, and disruption of over 100 servers globally.

item.title: Cisco Warns of Critical ISE Flaw Allowing Unauthenticated Attackers to Execute Root Code
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco ISE and Cisco ISE-PIC; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20337; Summary: The vulnerability allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on the underlying operating system with elevated privileges. It affects ISE and ISE-PIC releases 3.3 and 3.4, regardless of device configuration.

item.title: Submarine Cables Face Increasing Threats Amid Geopolitical Tensions and Limited Repair Capacity
item.description:
FYSA:
This analysis highlights various vulnerabilities in the submarine cable ecosystem, including:
1. **Concentration of cables at landing stations**: The clustering of multiple submarine cables at single landing sites increases the likelihood that damage to or near a landing site will impact multiple cables. 2. **Limited repair capacity**: Repair vessels are focused on laying new cable systems, constraining their ability to respond immediately to cable faults, leading to extended repair times. 3. **Regulatory hurdles**: Complex and lengthy permitting processes for repair ships vary by national territory, prolonging repair timelines and exacerbating the impact of limited repair capacity.
These vulnerabilities can have significant consequences for global internet connectivity, highlighting the need for investments in streamlining repair processes and expanding cable ship repair capacity to mitigate potential disruptions.

item.title: Co-op confirms data of 6.5 million members stolen in cyberattack
item.description:
A massive cyberattack on UK retailer Co-op resulted in the theft of personal data for 6.5 million members. The attackers accessed and stole Windows domain's Windows NTDS.dit file, which contains password hashes for Windows accounts.
FYSA: Threat actors associated with Scattered Spider were behind the Co-op cyberattack, as well as other attacks on M&S, Harrods, and MGM Resorts.

item.title: U.S. Army soldier pleads guilty to extorting 10 tech, telecom firms
item.description: A 21-year-old former U.S. Army soldier pleaded guilty to charges of hacking and extorting at least ten telecommunications and technology companies in the country. The man, Cameron John Wagenius, used online accounts associated with the nickname “kiberphant0m” and conspired with others to defraud victim organizations by obtaining login credentials for their protected computer networks.

item.title: Google finds custom backdoor being installed on SonicWall network devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; CVE(s): 2024-38475; Summary: UNC6148 exploited vulnerabilities in SMA appliances, gaining local administrator credentials and valid session tokens. They may have used infostealer logs or credential marketplaces to obtain credentials. A reverse shell was installed, providing a web interface for running commands and installing Overstep. The motivations of the group and what they do after Overstep is installed are unknown.

item.title: Cracked Apps Delivering Infostealers Identified as Leading Attack Vector in June 2025
item.description: The article discusses infostealer malware masquerading as keygens and cracked software, which uses advanced SEO poisoning to elevate malicious distribution sites in search results. It highlights the diversity of infostealers, including variants like LummaC2, Rhadamanthys, ACRStealer, Vidar, and StealC, and notes their evolving sophistication through techniques like evasion, deception, and anti-analysis mechanisms.

item.title: Hackers Leverage 607 Malicious Domains to Spread APK Malware with Remote Command Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; CVE(s): Janus vulnerability on Android versions 5.0 through 8.0 (None); Summary: Rogue domains were used in a large-scale phishing campaign to spread fake Telegram Messenger application files (APKs) over the course of a month, leveraging QR codes and centralized redirection for efficient malware delivery. The malicious APKs employ cleartext traffic protocols, grant broad permissions, and integrate MediaPlayer invocations and socket-based callbacks for remote command execution.

item.title: Louis Vuitton says regional data breaches tied to same cyberattack
item.description: The article reports a data breach at luxury fashion giant Louis Vuitton, which affected customers in the UK, South Korea, and Turkey. The breach is believed to be linked to the ShinyHunters extortion group.

item.title: Threat Actors Weaponize WordPress Sites to Redirect Visitors to Malicious Domains
item.description: The article describes a sophisticated malware campaign targeting WordPress websites, where threat actors embedded malicious code within core files to facilitate unauthorized redirects and SEO poisoning. The malware uses obfuscation techniques and bot-evasion tactics to evade detection, and can manipulate search engine rankings by injecting fake sitemaps and verifying with Google Search Console.

item.title: Operation Eastwood Targets NoName057(16) in Global Crackdown
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability but rather discusses an international law enforcement operation called Operation Eastwood, which targeted a pro-Russian hacktivist group known as NoName057(16). The group was responsible for carrying out widespread DDoS attacks against Ukraine and other perceived enemies of Russia.

item.title: SquidLoader Deploys Stealthy Malware with Near-Zero Detection to Evade Security Measures
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SquidLoader; CVE(s): None; Summary: A new variant of SquidLoader malware has been discovered, which achieves near-zero detection rates on platforms like VirusTotal by leveraging advanced anti-analysis, anti-sandbox, and anti-debugging mechanisms. The malware deploys Cobalt Strike Beacons for remote access and contains a multi-stage infection process with various evasion techniques, including anti-emulation tricks and API resolution via PEB walking.

item.title: Hackers Leverage Microsoft Teams to Spread Matanbuchus 3.0 Malware to Targeted Firms
item.description: Matanbuchus 3.0 is a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) that packs significant features to enhance its stealth and evade detection. It can be used as a conduit for next-stage payloads, including Cobalt Strike beacons and ransomware. The loader is often deployed using hands-on social engineering tactics, making it more targeted and coordinated than typical commodity loaders.

item.title: Cloudflare says 1.1.1.1 outage not caused by attack or BGP hijack
item.description: The article explains that the recent 1.1.1.1 Resolver service outage was caused by an internal misconfiguration at Cloudflare, not a cyberattack or BGP hijack incident. The misconfiguration occurred due to a configuration change for a future Data Localization Suite (DLS) performed on June 6, which mistakenly linked 1.1.1.1 Resolver IP prefixes to a non-production DLS service.

item.title: SonicWall SMA devices hacked with OVERSTEP rootkit tied to ransomware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall Secure Mobile Access appliances (SMA 100 Series); CVE(s): CVE-2021-20038, CVE-2024-38475, CVE-2021-20035, CVE-2021-20039, CVE-2025-32819; Summary: The article describes a previously unseen malware called OVERSTEP that modifies the boot process of fully-patched but no longer supported SonicWall SMA appliances. The backdoor allows hackers to hide malicious components, maintain persistent access on the device, and steal sensitive credentials.

item.title: ZDI-25-603: Autodesk Revit RTE File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit, requiring user interaction. The flaw exists in the parsing of RTE files due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, leading to a read past the end of an allocated object.

item.title: New Fortinet FortiWeb hacks likely linked to public RCE exploits
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Fortinet FortiWeb; CVE(s): CVE-2025-25257; Summary: A remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability tracked as CVE-2025-25257 affects FortiWeb 7.6.0 through 7.6.3, 7.4.0 through 7.4.7, and 7.0.0 through 7.0.10. The vulnerability allows an unauthenticated attacker to execute unauthorized SQL code or commands via crafted HTTP or HTTPS requests, which can lead to web shell infections.

item.title: Europol disrupts pro-Russian NoName057(16) DDoS hacktivist group
item.description: Operation Eastwood, an international law enforcement operation led by Europol and Eurojust, targeted the pro-Russian hacktivist group NoName057(16) responsible for DDoS attacks across Europe, Israel, and Ukraine. The operation disrupted over 100 servers hosting the group's infrastructure, resulted in two arrests, and issued seven European arrest warrants.

item.title: UNC6148 Backdoors Fully-Patched SonicWall SMA 100 Series Devices with OVERSTEP Rootkit
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SonicWall Secure Mobile Access (SMA) 100 series; CVE(s): CVE-2021-20035, CVE-2021-20038, CVE-2021-20039, CVE-2024-38475, CVE-2025-32819; Summary: A threat activity cluster has been observed targeting fully-patched end-of-life SonicWall SMA 100 series appliances to drop a backdoor called OVERSTEP. The attackers are believed to have initially gained access through the exploitation of known security flaws or obtained administrator credentials through information-stealing logs or credential marketplaces.

item.title: MITRE Launches AADAPT Framework to Secure Digital Assets
item.description: The MITRE organization has launched a new cybersecurity initiative called AADAPT (Adversarial Actions in Digital Asset Payment Technologies), which aims to help organizations detect and mitigate cyber threats in digital finance. The framework provides a structured approach to tackling risks in cryptocurrencies, smart contracts, decentralized applications, and blockchain systems, drawing on lessons from over 150 real-world incidents and expert sources across government, academia, and industry.

item.title: Lenovo Vantage Flaws Enable Attackers to Gain SYSTEM-Level Privileges
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Lenovo Vantage; CVE(s): 2025-6230, 2025-6231, 2025-6232; Summary: Multiple privilege escalation vulnerabilities in Lenovo Vantage allow unprivileged users to bypass authentication mechanisms and execute code with SYSTEM-level privileges, potentially leading to full system compromise. The flaws stem from Lenovo Vantage's modular architecture and expose JSON-based requests routed to add-ins defined in XML files.

item.title: Samsung WLAN AP Flaws Let Remote Attackers Run Commands as Root
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Samsung WEA453e Wireless Access Point; CVE(s): None; Summary: The WEA453e wireless access point has a critical chain of vulnerabilities that allows unauthenticated remote attackers to execute commands with full administrative privileges. The vulnerability chain begins with a reflected cross-site scripting (XSS) flaw and ends with local file inclusion (LFI) and command injection, allowing attackers to read sensitive files and gain root-level access without authentication.

item.title: Chinese ‘Salt Typhoon’ Hackers Infiltrated US National Guard Network for Almost a Year
item.description: A sophisticated advanced persistent threat (APT) group, known as Salt Typhoon, has successfully penetrated a U.S. state's Army National Guard network, enabling potential exfiltration of sensitive military and law enforcement data. The intrusion leveraged lateral movement techniques across interconnected systems, highlighting vulnerabilities in hybrid federal-state infrastructures.

item.title: Windows Secure Boot Certificate Expired in June, Microsoft Issues Warning
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Secure Boot certificates used by most Windows devices are scheduled to expire starting in June 2026, potentially affecting device functionality and security. If not properly updated, affected devices may encounter boot failures or security vulnerabilities, leaving systems exposed to malware attacks.

item.title: Google’s AI ‘Big Sleep’ Detects Critical SQLite 0-Day, Halts Ongoing Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SQLite; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6965; Summary: A zero-day vulnerability was found in SQLite by Google's AI agent "Big Sleep", which allowed it to stop exploitation attempts before widespread attacks could occur. The vulnerability was detected using threat intelligence and advanced code analysis, demonstrating a proactive approach to predictive threat prevention.

item.title: Critical Golden dMSA Attack in Windows Server 2025 Enables Cross-Domain Attacks and Persistent Access
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Windows Server 2025; CVE(s): None; Summary: A critical design flaw in Delegated Managed Service Accounts (dMSAs) allows for high-impact attacks, enabling cross-domain lateral movement and persistent access to all managed service accounts and their resources across Active Directory. Exploitation requires possession of a Key Distribution Service (KDS) root key, which is typically only available to privileged accounts.

item.title: Dark Partners Hacker Group Drains Crypto Wallets Using Fake AI Tools and VPN Services
item.description: Dark Partners, a financially driven cybercrime organization, has been planning massive cryptocurrency theft since May 2025 using over 250 malicious domains posing as AI tools, VPN services, and software brands. The group's infrastructure facilitates data harvesting from victims across multiple countries, with a focus on cryptocurrency, blockchain, technology, financial services, and VPN sectors.

item.title: Gmail Message Exploit Triggers Code Execution in Claude, Bypassing Protections
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Claude Desktop; CVE(s): None; Summary: A cybersecurity researcher demonstrated a code execution attack on Claude Desktop, an AI assistant application, by leveraging the Model Context Protocol (MCP) and exploiting compositional risk. The attack did not rely on any vulnerabilities in individual MCP servers but rather the combination of untrusted input sources, excessive execution permissions, and lack of contextual guardrails between different tools.

item.title: AI Agents Act Like Employees With Root Access—Here's How to Regain Control
item.description:
The article highlights the importance of identity-first security in securing generative AI systems. It warns that most organizations are not securing their AI deployments properly and that every LLM access point or website is a new identity edge that can be exploited. The article emphasizes the need for phishing-resistant MFA, granular RBAC, and continuous device trust enforcement to eliminate AI access risk without hindering innovation.
FYSA: The threat surface of AI systems expands internal attack surfaces, especially if access control and identity segmentation aren't enforced at runtime. Third-party tools can be misused or accessed by unauthorized users, or corporate users on personal accounts, where governance gaps exist.

item.title: Oracle Issues Critical Update Fixing 309 Vulnerabilities Across Products
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle; CVE(s): 309 (None); Summary: The Oracle July 2025 Critical Patch Update addresses 309 security vulnerabilities across its product portfolio, including Oracle Database Server, MySQL Server, WebLogic Server, Java SE, and other products. The update affects multiple version ranges, with some affecting software dating back several years. The vulnerabilities can be exploited remotely without authentication, leading to unauthorized access, data breaches, and system compromise.

item.title: Hackers exploit a blind spot by hiding malware inside DNS records
item.description: The article discusses the use of Domain Name System (DNS) records to host malicious PowerShell scripts. Researchers have found that threat actors are using TXT records to embed attacker-devised text into documents or files being analyzed by AI chatbots, which can be exploited through prompt injections. This technique allows attackers to manipulate the chatbot's behavior and achieve malicious objectives.

item.title: NimDoor MacOS Malware Abuses Zoom SDK Updates to Steal Keychain Credentials
item.description: SentinelOne researchers discovered NimDoor, a sophisticated MacOS malware campaign attributed to North Korean-affiliated attackers (Stardust Chollima gang) targeting the bitcoin industry, exploiting social engineering tactics to steal sensitive data. The malware uses Nim-compiled binaries and process injection techniques for stealthy operations.

item.title: Grok 4 benchmark results: Tops math, ranks second in coding
item.description: The article discusses various AI-related topics, including the performance of Grok 4, a reasoning model, in different domains such as coding and math. It also mentions the threat actors' techniques used for cloud-fluent attacks, which are surprisingly simple despite growing sophistication. Additionally, it touches on upcoming developments in the AI space, including the potential launch of Grok 3.5 and GPT-5 models.

item.title: Konfety Android Malware Exploits ZIP Tricks to Masquerade as Legit Apps on Google Play
item.description: The Konfety Android malware uses complex ZIP-level changes to avoid detection and mimic genuine apps on the Google Play Store, employing an "evil-twin" strategy, runtime decryption, and deceptive manifest declarations. It can redirect users to fraudulent websites, initiate unwanted app sideloads, and severely impact user privacy and device integrity.

item.title: ZDI-25-598: Oracle VirtualBox BusLogic Uninitialized Memory Information Disclosure Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53025; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to disclose sensitive information on affected installations of Oracle VirtualBox. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute high-privileged code on the target guest system in order to exploit this vulnerability, which results from the lack of proper initialization of memory prior to accessing it.

item.title: ZDI-25-599: Oracle VirtualBox LSILogic Uninitialized Memory Information Disclosure Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53026; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to disclose sensitive information on affected installations of Oracle VirtualBox. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute high-privileged code on the target guest system in order to exploit this vulnerability, and it can be leveraged with other vulnerabilities to execute code in the context of the hypervisor.

item.title: ZDI-25-600: (Pwn2Own) Oracle VirtualBox VMSVGA Out-Of-Bounds Write Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53028; Summary: The vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of Oracle VirtualBox by exploiting an out-of-bounds write local privilege escalation flaw in the VMSVGA virtual device, which can be leveraged to execute arbitrary code in the context of the hypervisor.

item.title: ZDI-25-601: (Pwn2Own) Oracle VirtualBox VMSVGA Integer Overflow Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53024; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of Oracle VirtualBox by exploiting an integer overflow in the VMSVGA virtual device. An attacker must first obtain high-privileged code execution on the target guest system to exploit this flaw, which results from a lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-602: (Pwn2Own) Oracle VirtualBox OHCI USB Controller Time-Of-Check Time-Of-Use Local Privilege Escalation Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Oracle VirtualBox; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53027; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to escalate privileges on affected installations of Oracle VirtualBox by exploiting a lack of proper locking when performing operations on an object in the virtual OHCI USB controller. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute high-privileged code on the target guest system to exploit this vulnerability, which can then be used to execute arbitrary code in the context of the hypervisor.

item.title: Talos IR ransomware engagements and the significance of timeliness in incident response
item.description:
FYSA:
The article appears to be a case study on a cybersecurity incident involving a series of malicious activities by an attacker. The analyst's analysis reveals that the attack involved multiple tools and techniques, including social engineering, malware deployment, data exfiltration, and command and control (C2) communication.
From a security perspective, several concerns are raised:
1. **Lack of robust security controls**: The article highlights the importance of implementing strong security controls to prevent unauthorized access and data breaches. 2. **Inadequate logging and monitoring**: The analyst notes that the attack was only detected due to the victim's logging and monitoring efforts. This emphasizes the need for organizations to maintain comprehensive logging and monitoring capabilities. 3. **Malware deployment**: The article highlights the importance of maintaining up-to-date antivirus software and implementing sandboxing or virtualization technologies to contain malware outbreaks. 4. **Command and control (C2) communication**: The analyst notes that the attacker used C2 servers to communicate with compromised hosts. This underscores the need for organizations to implement robust C2 detection and mitigation strategies.
In terms of specific vulnerabilities, the article does not discuss any particular software, hardware, or firmware vulnerabilities. However, it highlights the importance of keeping systems and applications up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.
Overall, the article provides valuable insights into the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by attackers and emphasizes the need for organizations to prioritize robust security controls, logging, monitoring, and incident response capabilities.

item.title: Email Filters Defeated by Polyglot File Trick Used in Malware Campaigns
item.description: This article discusses advanced techniques used by attackers to evade email filters and successfully send phishing payloads. The techniques include the use of polyglot files, which can be interpreted as multiple file formats simultaneously, allowing malicious content to appear benign to security scanners.

item.title: Google fixes actively exploited sandbox escape zero day in Chrome
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6558; Summary: The vulnerability, identified as CVE-2025-6558, is a high-severity issue in ANGLE and GPU that affects Google Chrome versions before 138.0.7204.157. It allows an attacker to perform a sandbox escape by using a specially crafted HTML page, potentially executing arbitrary code within the browser's GPU process.

item.title: Massive DDoS Attack Slams Internet with 7.3 Tbps and 4.8 Billion Packets Per Second
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article reports on a massive DDoS attack mitigated by Cloudflare, peaking at 7.3 terabits per second (Tbps) and 4.8 billion packets per second (Bpps). The report highlights the increasing frequency and intensity of DDoS attacks, with a focus on HTTP and L3/4 attacks, as well as emerging threats like Teeworlds and RIPv1 floods.

item.title: New Konfety Malware Variant Evades Detection by Manipulating APKs and Dynamic Code
item.description: The article discusses a sophisticated variant of an Android malware called Konfety that uses the evil twin technique for ad fraud. The malware employs dynamic code loading, obfuscation, and deception to evade detection. It can redirect users to malicious websites, prompt unwanted app installs, and trigger spam-like notifications.

item.title: Urgent: Google Releases Critical Chrome Update for CVE-2025-6558 Exploit Active in the Wild
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6558; Summary: The high-severity vulnerability (CVSS score: 8.8) allows a remote attacker to potentially perform a sandbox escape via a crafted HTML page, exploiting an incorrect validation of untrusted input in the browser's ANGLE and GPU components, allowing attackers to break out of the browser's security bubble and interact with the underlying system.

item.title: Deepfakes. Fake Recruiters. Cloned CFOs — Learn How to Stop AI-Driven Attacks in Real Time
item.description: Social engineering attacks are evolving with the use of generative AI, stolen branding assets, and deepfake tools, allowing attackers to mimic executives, hijack social channels, and create convincing fakes. Modern attacks involve long-term, multi-channel campaigns across email, LinkedIn, SMS, and support portals, targeting employees, customers, and partners.

item.title: Command-Line Editor Vim Hit by Vulnerability Allowing File Overwrites
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Vim; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53906; Summary: The vulnerability allows attackers to overwrite arbitrary files on users' systems by exploiting a path traversal issue in Vim's zip.vim plugin when opening specially crafted zip archives. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution, compromising entire systems.

item.title: Hackers Exploit Ivanti and Fortinet VPN Vulnerabilities in Attacks on Japanese Companies
item.description: The article reports on a surge in cyber espionage campaigns against Japanese companies, primarily targeting North Korean threat actors. These campaigns aim to exfiltrate sensitive data, including manufacturing blueprints and personal information, using various tactics such as spear phishing, malware, and social engineering.

item.title: Curl 8.15.0 Officially Released: 233 Bugs Fixed in Major Update
item.description: The article discusses the release of Curl 8.15.0, which addresses over 230 bugs and streamlines its internal architecture. The update removes support for Apple's Secure Transport API and BearSSL library to reduce maintenance overhead and promote adoption of widely tested TLS providers like OpenSSL. The article highlights the community-driven nature of the project, with many newcomers contributing to the codebase.

item.title: Authorities Take Down ‘Diskstation’ Ransomware Gang Targeting Synology NAS Globally
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Synology NAS systems; CVE(s): None; Summary: The "Diskstation" ransomware operation targeted Synology Network Attached Storage (NAS) systems worldwide, exploiting vulnerabilities to encrypt entire organizational datasets. The attackers specifically targeted these systems for data storage and backup solutions, allowing them to maximize their leverage over victims.

item.title: Abacus Dark Web Market Suspected of Exit Scam with Held Bitcoin Funds
item.description: The largest Bitcoin-enabled Western darknet marketplace, Abacus Market, has gone offline amid suspicions of an exit scam that may have cost users millions of dollars in held cryptocurrency funds. The market's administrators likely shut down operations and disappeared with users' deposits, leaving behind a trail of frozen funds and delayed transactions.

item.title: Google AI "Big Sleep" Stops Exploitation of Critical SQLite Vulnerability Before Hackers Act
item.description: Vulnerable Product: SQLite; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6965; Summary: The vulnerability is a memory corruption flaw affecting all versions prior to 3.50.2, which could allow an attacker to cause an integer overflow resulting in read off the end of an array.

item.title: Former U.S. Army Member Pleads Guilty in Telecom Hacking Case
item.description: A 21-year-old former U.S. Army soldier has pleaded guilty to participating in a sophisticated cybercrime operation that targeted telecommunications companies through hacking, data theft, and extortion schemes. The conspiracy involved at least 10 victim organizations, using specialized hacking tools and Telegram group chats to coordinate activities.

item.title: Node.js Vulnerabilities Leave Windows Apps Vulnerable to Path Traversal and HashDoS
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Node.js; CVE(s): CVE-2025-27210, CVE-2025-27209; Summary: Two high-severity vulnerabilities affecting Windows applications, including denial-of-service attacks. The first vulnerability allows attackers to bypass path traversal protection mechanisms, while the second introduces a HashDoS vulnerability through changes in the V8 JavaScript engine's string hashing implementation.

item.title: VMware ESXi and Workstation Vulnerabilities Allow Host-Level Code Execution
item.description: Vulnerable Product: VMware; CVE(s): CVE-2025-41236, CVE-2025-41237, CVE-2025-41238, CVE-2025-41239; Summary: Four critical vulnerabilities in VMware's virtualization suite allow attackers to escape virtual machines and execute code directly on host systems. The flaws affect ESXi, Workstation, Fusion, and VMware Tools across enterprise and desktop environments.

item.title: OpenAI's image model gets built-in style feature on ChatGPT
item.description:
The article does not discuss a vulnerability. It appears to be focused on updates and features of OpenAI's image generation model, ChatGPT, including the introduction of a "Style" feature that allows users to create images in different styles.
FYSA: The article mentions threat actors using simple techniques for cloud attacks and notes that attackers are leveraging ChatGPT to write malware.

item.title: Abacus dark web drug market goes offline in suspected exit scam
item.description: Abacus Market, the largest Western darknet marketplace supporting Bitcoin payments, has shut down its public infrastructure, suspected to be an exit scam or covert law enforcement operation. The market reportedly enabled transactions of nearly $100 million worth of Bitcoin and possibly up to $300 million when including Monero transactions. User deposits dropped significantly after withdrawal delays, leading many to believe it was an exit scam rather than a law enforcement takedown.

item.title: Windows KB5064489 emergency update fixes Azure VM launch issues
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Azure; CVE(s): None; Summary: The bug prevented Azure virtual machines from launching when Trusted Launch setting was disabled and Virtualization-Based Security (VBS) was enabled, affecting Windows Server 2025 and Windows 11 24H2. The issue was caused by a secure kernel initialization problem and has been fixed with the KB5064489 out-of-band update.

item.title: North Korean XORIndex malware hidden in 67 malicious npm packages
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Node Package Manager (npm); CVE(s): None; Summary: North Korean threat actors uploaded 67 malicious packages to npm, which collectively received over 17,000 downloads. The packages were designed to deliver a new malware loader called XORIndex, which can collect host and network data, profile victims, and download additional payloads.

item.title: Police disrupt “Diskstation” ransomware gang attacking NAS devices
item.description: This article discusses a law enforcement operation codenamed 'Operation Elicius' that dismantled a Romanian ransomware gang known as 'Diskstation', which targeted Synology Network-Attached Storage (NAS) devices. The gang encrypted the systems of several companies, paralyzing their businesses, and demanded ransom payments ranging from $10,000 to hundreds of thousands of dollars.

item.title: Hyper-Volumetric DDoS Attacks Reach Record 7.3 Tbps, Targeting Key Global Sectors
item.description: This article discusses a significant increase in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks mitigated by Cloudflare in the second quarter of 2025. The article highlights the rise of hyper-volumetric DDoS attacks, which peaked at 7.3 terabits per second and 4.8 billion packets per second within a span of 45 seconds. It also discusses the increasing use of targeted probes by attackers to find weak spots and slip past defenses.

item.title: Ransomware Attack on Albemarle County Exposes Residents’ Personal Information
item.description: Albemarle County, Virginia, fell victim to a sophisticated ransomware attack despite having robust defenses in place, including endpoint detection and response systems, multi-factor authentication, and regular vulnerability patching. The attack exploited on-premises servers, potentially exposing sensitive personally identifiable information (PII) of local government and public school employees, as well as county residents.

item.title: Newly Emerged GLOBAL GROUP RaaS Expands Operations with AI-Driven Negotiation Tools
item.description: This article discusses a new ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) operation called GLOBAL GROUP that has targeted various sectors in Australia, Brazil, Europe, and the United States. The RaaS platform is designed to facilitate initial access brokers to deploy the ransomware by weaponizing access to vulnerable edge appliances from Cisco, Fortinet, and Palo Alto Networks.

item.title: Microsoft Explains How Security Copilot in Intune and Entra Supports Security and IT Teams
item.description: None (The article is not about a vulnerability or cybersecurity-relevant content, but rather discusses Microsoft's Security Copilot tool and its features for improving security and IT operations.)

item.title: Federal IT Contractor to Pay $14.75M for False Cybersecurity Services Claims
item.description: The article discusses a settlement between Hill ASC Inc. and the U.S. Department of Justice regarding allegations of violating the False Claims Act through improper billing practices under a General Services Administration (GSA) Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) contract. The alleged violations include fraudulent claims for IT personnel, unauthorized billing for cybersecurity services, and unapproved fees on government invoices.

item.title: DShield Honeypot Scanning Hits Record High with Over 1 Million Logs in a Single Day
item.description: The article reports an unusual surge in cyber reconnaissance activity detected by DShield honeypots, with web logs exceeding 1 GB daily and peaking at nearly 58 GB. The increase is attributed to automated scanning from overlapping subnets targeting specific URL paths, potentially probing for vulnerabilities or gathering intelligence for future exploits.

item.title: Iranian Threat Actors Target U.S. Critical Infrastructure, Including Water Systems
item.description: Intelligence Group 13, an elite unit within the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), has been conducting asymmetric cyber operations in response to U.S. attacks on Iranian nuclear sites. The group uses advanced persistent threat (APT) techniques, including phishing-driven credential theft, open-source intelligence harvesting, and custom malware deployment for reconnaissance and sabotage. Its operations extend beyond technical compromise, incorporating psychological elements through propaganda fronts like CyberAveng3rs, which disseminates defacement screenshots, operational leaks, and taunting messages via Telegram and Instagram channels.

item.title: Kafbat UI Vulnerabilities Allow Arbitrary Code Execution via JMX Services
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Kafbat UI; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49127; Summary: The vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code by exploiting unsafe deserialization in Kafbat UI's metrics collection system. Attackers can specify malicious JMX servers that return crafted serialized objects, enabling Java deserialization gadget chains and complete system compromise.

item.title: Octalyn Stealer Harvests VPN Configs, Passwords, and Cookies in Organized Folder Structure
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Octalyn Forensic Toolkit; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Octalyn Forensic Toolkit is a credential stealer that poses as a research tool for red teaming and digital forensics. It can extract sensitive data including browser passwords, cookies, autofill information, Discord and Telegram tokens, VPN configurations, gaming account details, and cryptocurrency wallet artifacts. The toolkit's payload establishes persistence via Windows Startup folder entries and registry modifications, and can exfiltrate stolen data over TLS-secured connections to api.telegram.org.

item.title: Android malware Konfety uses malformed APKs to evade detection
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Konfety; CVE(s): None; Summary: The latest variant of the Konfety Android malware uses a malformed ZIP structure, obfuscation methods, and dynamic code loading to evade analysis and detection. It poses as a legitimate app, redirects users to malicious sites, pushes unwanted app installs, and steals information such as installed apps, network configuration, and system details.

item.title: GLOBAL GROUP RaaS Adds AI-Powered Negotiation Feature for Ransom Demands
item.description: The article discusses a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) operation called GLOBAL GROUP that has deployed an AI-driven negotiation tool to pressure victims into paying ransoms. The operation uses Initial Access Brokers (IABs) to sell compromised VPN appliances and webshells, and its affiliates can deploy customized ransomware payloads that take advantage of chaos and speed to maximize damage before traditional endpoint defenses can react.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Exploit 67 Malicious npm Packages to Spread XORIndex Malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Socket Threat Research Team discovered a software supply chain attack using the XORIndex malware loader, which has not been previously reported, attributed to North Korean state-backed actors. The attackers infiltrated the npm registry with 67 malicious packages, amassing over 17,000 downloads collectively, targeting developers, job seekers, and cryptocurrency holders by exfiltrating sensitive credentials and wallet data through a chain of malware stages.

item.title: BaitTrap Reveals Global Web of 17,000+ Fraud-Promoting Fake News Sites
item.description: A network of over 17,000 "Baiting News Sites" (BNS) has been discovered by cybersecurity firm CTM360, which are designed to disseminate investment fraud globally. These sites masquerade as authoritative news entities and use advanced social engineering tactics to target unsuspecting users with false information about lucrative investment opportunities.

item.title: New AsyncRAT Forks Discovered Featuring Screamer Tool and USB Malware Spreader
item.description: Vulnerable Product: AsyncRAT; CVE(s): None; Summary: The article describes two new variants of the AsyncRAT remote access trojan (RAT) that introduce a psychological warfare component and enhanced propagation mechanisms. The "Screamer" plugin manipulates Windows audio APIs to disorient victims, while the USB malware spreader component transforms AsyncRAT into a self-replicating worm capable of bridging air-gapped networks.

item.title: Hitachi Energy Asset Suite
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Hitachi Energy Equipment, including Asset Suite AnyWhere for Inventory (AWI) Android mobile app and Asset Suite 9 series; CVE(s): CVE-2019-9262, CVE-2019-9429, CVE-2019-9256, CVE-2019-9290, CVE-2025-1484, CVE-2025-2500; Summary: Multiple vulnerabilities in Hitachi Energy's Asset Suite product allow for unauthorized access, remote code execution, and privilege escalation.

item.title: LITEON IC48A and IC80A EV Chargers
item.description: Vulnerable Product: LITEONE IC48A and IC80A; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7357; Summary: Successful exploitation of the plaintext storage of a password vulnerability in Liteon EV chargers could allow an attacker to access sensitive information, with potential impacts on commercial facilities, energy, and transportation systems worldwide.

item.title: ABB RMC-100
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ABB RMC-100; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6071, CVE-2025-6072, CVE-2025-6073, CVE-2025-6074; Summary: The ABB RMC-100 has several vulnerabilities that allow an attacker to gain unauthenticated access to MQTT configuration data, cause a denial-of-service condition on the MQTT configuration web server (REST interface), or decrypt encrypted MQTT broker credentials.

item.title: CISA Releases Six Industrial Control Systems Advisories
item.description: CISA released six Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories on July 15, 2025, providing timely information about current security issues, vulnerabilities, and exploits surrounding ICS. The advisories cover various products from Hitachi Energy, ABB, LITEON, Schneider Electric, and others. Users and administrators are encouraged to review the advisories for technical details and mitigations.

item.title: Hacktivists Launch Attacks on ICS Systems to Exfiltrate Sensitive Information
item.description: The article highlights the increasing intensity of hacktivist attacks targeting Industrial Control Systems (ICS), with a focus on Operational Technology (OT) environments, Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems, and Human-Machine Interfaces (HMIs).

item.title: OpenAI's ChatGPT-powered browser is codenamed 'Aura'
item.description: Vulnerable Product: None; FYSA: While cloud attacks may be growing more sophisticated, attackers still succeed with surprisingly simple techniques. This report reveals 8 key techniques used by cloud-fluent threat actors.

item.title: Ransomware Threat Grows as Attackers Move Into VMware and Linux
item.description: The article highlights the increasing trend of ransomware attacks targeting Linux environments, which were previously considered secure due to their reliability and inherent security. Threat actors are now engineering sophisticated Linux-specific ransomware variants, exploiting ubiquity in critical applications, APIs, DevOps pipelines, and virtualized infrastructures.

item.title: 14 Hackers Arrested in Massive Tax Fraud Scheme, Authorities Confirm
item.description: Authorities have arrested 14 individuals for a sophisticated tax fraud scheme that exploited stolen personal data to submit fraudulent claims worth over £1 million. The operation involved international cooperation between UK and Romanian law enforcement agencies, demonstrating the growing collaboration in combating cross-border cybercrime.

item.title: State-Backed HazyBeacon Malware Uses AWS Lambda to Steal Data from SE Asian Governments
item.description: The article discusses a previously undocumented Windows backdoor called HazyBeacon, which targets government agencies in Southeast Asia. The malware uses DLL side-loading techniques to deploy it on compromised hosts and establishes communication with an attacker-controlled URL to execute arbitrary commands and download additional payloads.

item.title: LaRecipe Tool with 2.3M Downloads Found Vulnerable to Full Server Takeover
item.description: Vulnerable Product: torch/larecipe; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53833; Summary: A critical Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) vulnerability, identified as CVE-2025-53833, allows attackers to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable systems, leading to Remote Code Execution (RCE). The vulnerability affects all versions prior to 2.8.1 and requires no authentication or user interaction.

item.title: Securing Agentic AI: How to Protect the Invisible Identity Access
item.description: This article is not about a vulnerability, but rather discusses the security implications of AI agents in cloud environments. It highlights the need for visibility into non-human identities (NHIs) and emphasizes the importance of applying least privilege and automation to ensure secure use of AI agents.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Exploit Zoom Invites in Attacks on Crypto Companies
item.description: The article describes an ongoing malware campaign orchestrated by North Korean threat actors targeting individuals and organizations within the Web3, cryptocurrency, and blockchain industries. The malware uses spear-phishing tactics, fake job opportunities, and social engineering to deploy a multi-stage attack chain that compromises macOS systems and exfiltrates sensitive data, including cryptocurrency wallet credentials and personal information.

item.title: AsyncRAT's Open-Source Code Sparks Surge in Dangerous Malware Variants Across the Globe
item.description: Vulnerable Product: AsyncRAT; CVE(s): None; Summary: AsyncRAT is a widely used remote access trojan that has evolved over the years, with its open-source nature allowing it to be modified and distributed by threat actors. It can capture screenshots, log keystrokes, steal credentials, and allow attackers to commandeer infected systems stealthily. The malware has spawned various variants, including DCRat, Venom RAT, and others, which have added new features and evasion techniques.

item.title: ZDI-25-592: Autodesk Revit RVT File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Write Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit by parsing out-of-bounds write RVT files, requiring user interaction. The specific flaw exists within the lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, resulting in a write past the end of an allocated object.

item.title: ZDI-25-593: Autodesk Revit RVT File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit by parsing out-of-bounds read remote code execution. User interaction is required, and the issue results from lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, which can result in a read past the end of an allocated object.

item.title: ZDI-25-594: Autodesk Revit RFA File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit by parsing out-of-bounds read RFA files. User interaction is required, as the target must visit a malicious page or open a malicious file. The issue results from the lack of proper validation of user-supplied data, which can result in a read past the end of an allocated buffer.

item.title: ZDI-25-595: Autodesk Revit RFA File Parsing Out-Of-Bounds Read Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: The vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit by exploiting an out-of-bounds read in the parsing of RFA files. User interaction is required, and the issue results from a lack of proper validation of user-supplied data.

item.title: ZDI-25-596: Autodesk Revit RTE File Parsing Heap-based Buffer Overflow Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5040; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit, requiring user interaction to exploit. The flaw exists in the parsing of RTE files due to lack of proper validation of user-supplied data prior to copying it to a fixed-length heap-based buffer.

item.title: ZDI-25-597: Autodesk Revit RFA File Parsing Memory Corruption Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Autodesk Revit; CVE(s): CVE-2025-5037; Summary: This vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code on affected installations of Autodesk Revit by exploiting memory corruption in the parsing of RFA files. User interaction is required, and an attacker can leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.

item.title: British Citizen Sentenced for Islamophobic WiFi Hack at UK Train Stations
item.description: The article reports on a 37-year-old individual, John Andreas Wik, who was sentenced to 24 months in prison, suspended for two years, for orchestrating an Islamophobic hack of free WiFi landing pages at multiple train stations across Britain. The hack caused distress and fear among commuters, highlighting the misuse of digital infrastructure to spread hateful content.

item.title: MITRE Launches AADAPT Framework to Counter Real-World Attacks on Digital Asset Systems
item.description: The MITRE Corporation has released its AADAPT framework, a comprehensive knowledge base for understanding and countering sophisticated attacks targeting digital asset management systems, cryptocurrency exchanges, and blockchain infrastructure. The framework organizes threat intelligence into a twelve-tactic matrix covering the attack lifecycle, including techniques such as Channel Wormholing, Quantum Efficient Factorization, Chain Reorganization attacks, and Partial Payments Attacks.

item.title: Apache Tomcat Coyote Flaw Allows Attackers to Launch DoS Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Apache Tomcat; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Tomcat Coyote module contains a vulnerability that allows malicious actors to orchestrate denial-of-service (DoS) attacks by manipulating stream concurrency limits in HTTP/2 protocol handling. This uncontrolled resource consumption issue can exhaust server threads, memory, or CPU resources, rendering the server unresponsive to legitimate requests.

item.title: NCC Advises Immediate Windows 11 Upgrade to Strengthen Cyberattack Defenses
item.description: The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has released recommended configuration packs for Microsoft Windows operating systems to improve security settings, warning that the end-of-life (EOL) of Windows 10 is imminent on October 14, 2025. The article highlights the risks of unpatched vulnerabilities and emphasizes the importance of transitioning to Windows 11, which offers enhanced security features such as Trusted Platform Module (TPM) 2.0, Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI), and Secure Boot capabilities.

item.title: Cybercriminals Clone CNN, BBC, and CNBC Sites to Lure Victims into Investment Fraud
item.description: A sprawling cybercrime syndicate has been uncovered, orchestrating a large-scale phishing and investment fraud campaign by cloning legitimate news outlets. The operation uses domain spoofing, typosquatting, and social engineering tactics to target users in the United States and other countries, with over 17,000 baiting websites created across 50 countries.

item.title: Government Organizations Targeted via AWS Lambda URL Endpoint Exploits
item.description: The CL-STA-1020 threat cluster targets government agencies in Southeast Asia with a previously undocumented Windows backdoor, HazyBeacon, which exploits AWS Lambda URLs to establish a stealthy command-and-control (C2) infrastructure.

item.title: PoC Released for High-Severity Git CLI Vulnerability Allowing Arbitrary File Writes
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Git; CVE(s): CVE-2025-48384; Summary: A critical vulnerability in Git's command-line interface allows arbitrary file writes and remote code execution on Linux and macOS systems. The vulnerability stems from a mismatch in Git's configuration parser behavior when processing control characters, enabling attackers to write malicious Git Hook scripts and achieve remote code execution.

item.title: CBI Uncovers Noida Tech Support Scam Targeting Victims in UK and Australia
item.description: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) has taken down a sophisticated global cybercrime network that targeted people in Australia and the United Kingdom with tech support frauds. The syndicate used social engineering tactics, VoIP systems, proxy servers, and anonymized networks to evade detection. The CBI's operation, called Chakra-V, highlights the evolving landscape of cyber-enabled fraud and emphasizes the importance of international cooperation in combating cyber threats.

item.title: ImageMagick Vulnerability Enables RCE via Malicious File Name Patterns
item.description: Vulnerable Product: ImageMagick; CVE(s): CVE-2025-53101; Summary: A critical remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability in ImageMagick's image processing library allows attackers to bypass stack buffer underwrite through carefully crafted filename templates. The flaw affects versions before 7.1.1-47 and 6.9.13-25, and has been addressed in versions 7.1.2-0 and 6.9.13-26.

item.title: North Korean Hackers Flood npm Registry with XORIndex Malware in Ongoing Attack Campaign
item.description: The North Korean threat actors linked to the Contagious Interview campaign have been publishing malicious packages on the npm registry, using software supply chain attacks to target developers. The packages, which include a previously undocumented malware loader codenamed XORIndex, have attracted over 17,000 downloads and incorporate known JavaScript loaders and stealers called BeaverTail, which is used to extract data from web browsers and cryptocurrency wallets, as well as deploy a Python backdoor referred to as InvisibleFerret.

item.title: Red Bull-Themed Phishing Attacks Target Job Seekers’ Credentials
item.description: This article discusses a phishing campaign targeting job seekers with spoofed Red Bull recruitment emails. The attackers leverage legitimate email services, transient VPS infrastructure, and brand impersonation to deliver malicious payloads that slip past SPF, DKIM, and DMARC checks.

item.title: DOGE Denizen Marko Elez Leaked API Key for xAI
item.description: A DOGE employee, Marko Elez, inadvertently published a private API key for xAI's large language models on GitHub, allowing access to at least 52 LLMs. The exposed key has not been revoked and is still functional, raising concerns about operational security and the handling of sensitive government information.

item.title: UK launches vulnerability research program for external experts
item.description: The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has launched a new Vulnerability Research Initiative (VRI) to strengthen relations with external cybersecurity experts, aiming to improve the discovery and sharing of critical insights with the community. This initiative will involve partnering with skilled external vulnerability researchers to identify flaws in specific products, assess mitigations, and disclose findings through the 'Equities Process' procedure.

item.title: Interlock ransomware adopts FileFix method to deliver malware
item.description: The Interlock ransomware gang has adopted a new technique called "FileFix" to drop a remote access trojan (RAT) on targeted systems. FileFix is a social engineering attack that weaponizes trusted Windows UI elements to trick users into executing malicious PowerShell or JavaScript code without displaying any security warnings.

item.title: Nvidia chips become the first GPUs to fall to Rowhammer bit-flip attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: NVIDIA GPUs (A6000 and other GDDR6-based GPUs in Nvidia’s Ampere generation); CVE(s): None; Summary: The article discusses a vulnerability known as GPUhammer, which exploits Rowhammer bit flips to flip bits inside discrete GPUs and target GDDR6 GPU memory modules. The vulnerability is mitigated by ECC, but using ECC can also cause miscorrections and silent data corruption if three or more bit flips occur in a code word.

item.title: The Unusual Suspect: Git Repos
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: Multiple; CVE(s): None; Summary: Exposed Git repositories are a critical risk for most enterprises, allowing attackers to silently create shadow access into core systems. This is not just about poor hygiene, but a systemic and growing supply chain risk. Attackers can weaponize exposed code repositories by harvesting secrets, pivoting to compromised infrastructure, and exploiting internal systems.
FYSA: The threat landscape surrounding Git repositories is expanding rapidly due to the growing complexity of DevOps practices, widespread reliance on public version control platforms like GitHub, and human error. Attackers can use exposed credentials and secrets to gain initial access into cloud environments, databases, SaaS platforms, and more.

item.title: New PHP-Based Interlock RAT Variant Uses FileFix Delivery Mechanism to Target Multiple Industries
item.description: The article discusses a new PHP variant of the Interlock remote access trojan (RAT) used by the Interlock ransomware group. The campaign involves compromised websites injecting JavaScript code that redirects users to fake CAPTCHA verification pages, leading to the deployment of NodeSnake or PHP variants of the RAT.

item.title: Gigabyte motherboards vulnerable to UEFI malware bypassing Secure Boot
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Gigabyte motherboard models; CVE(s): CVE-2025-7029, CVE-2025-7028, CVE-2025-7027, CVE-2025-7026; Summary: Dozens of Gigabyte motherboard models run on UEFI firmware vulnerable to security issues that allow planting bootkit malware that is invisible to the operating system and can survive reinstalls. The vulnerabilities could allow attackers with local or remote admin permissions to execute arbitrary code in System Management Mode (SMM), an environment isolated from the operating system and with more privileges on the machine.

item.title: Dark Web Profile: APT36
item.description: APT36 is a Pakistan-linked state-sponsored cyber-espionage group active since at least 2013. The group targets Indian government bodies, defense contractors, armed forces, diplomatic missions, and research institutions, using phishing, remote-access trojans, and deceptive infrastructure to conduct long-term intelligence-gathering operations. Despite lacking sophistication, APT36 is highly persistent and adaptive, leveraging new platforms and cloud services, and malvertising campaigns to remain effective across South Asia's geopolitical threat landscape.

item.title: Gigabyte UEFI Firmware Vulnerability Allows Code Execution in SMM Privileged Mode
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Gigabyte motherboard; CVE(s): CVE-2023-XXXX (none listed); Summary: The firmware of multiple Gigabyte motherboard models contains vulnerabilities that allow attackers to execute arbitrary code in System Management Mode (SMM), enabling persistent malware installation, bootkit persistence, and system control even after OS reinstallation.

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Scattered Spider Arrests, Car Exploits, macOS Malware, Fortinet RCE and More
item.description: This article appears to be a comprehensive cybersecurity news roundup, covering various topics and threats in the industry. It does not seem to discuss specific vulnerabilities in software, hardware, or firmware products. Instead, it covers issues such as botnets, ransomware groups, API client security risks, and other cybersecurity-related matters.

item.title: Malicious VSCode extension in Cursor IDE led to $500K crypto theft
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Open VSX, Visual Studio Code; CVE(s): None; Summary: A fake extension named "Solidity Language" was published on Open VSX, claiming to be a syntax highlighting tool for Ethereum smart contracts. In reality, it executed PowerShell scripts and installed remote access tools (Quasar RAT) and infostealers (PureLogs stealer). The extension was downloaded 54,000 times before being removed and inflated its install count by publishing an almost identical version under the name "solidity", which had nearly two million installs.

item.title: CISA Adds One Known Exploited Vulnerability to Catalog
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Wing FTP Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47812; Summary: A vulnerability in Wing FTP Server allows for improper neutralization of null bytes or NUL characters, making it a frequent attack vector for malicious cyber actors. This poses significant risks to the federal enterprise and requires timely remediation to protect against active threats.

item.title: Microsoft Explains How to Find and Stop Processes Blocking Files in Windows
item.description: This article provides guidance from Microsoft on resolving the "The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process" error message in Windows. The solutions include using built-in tools like Resource Monitor, Process Explorer, as well as command-line utilities like openfiles and Handle. These options cater to users of all skill levels, providing both graphical and command-line interfaces for resolving common system issues independently.

item.title: BitMart Breach, Naver Leak, qTox Exploit, and Credit Card Sales Detected on Dark Web
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: qTox; CVE(s): None; Summary: A 0-day exploit targeting qTox's secure messaging platform has been advertised for sale on a dark web forum, allowing Remote Code Execution (RCE), privilege escalation, API key theft, and manipulation of wallet addresses. The exploit is being sold for 10 BTC with video proof of functionality.
FYSA: Threat actors remain highly active across dark web forums, with multiple alarming developments this week including the alleged breach of BitMart's backend infrastructure, a claimed database leak affecting Naver Corporation, and the sale of Canadian credit card data and a dataset containing over 54,000 card records from the U.S. and U.K.

item.title: New Forensic Method Reveals Hidden Traces of RDP Exploits by Hackers
item.description: The article discusses advanced techniques for tracking attackers who use Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to move laterally through compromised networks. It highlights the ability to analyze RDP's bitmap caching mechanism to reveal forensic evidence of an attacker's activities, including their screen activity and copied passwords and sensitive data.

item.title: Weaponized Games: Threat Actors Target Gen Z Gamers Through Popular Titles
item.description: Sophisticated threat actor activities targeting the digitally native Gen Z population have been discovered by Kaspersky security researchers. Threat actors are exploiting popular games, streaming services, and anime to disseminate malware and harvest sensitive data through phishing schemes and social engineering tactics. Additionally, compromised accounts from these platforms are being repurposed for further phishing propagation or sold on underground markets.

item.title: Hackers Weaponize Compiled HTML Help to Deliver Malicious Payload
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Microsoft Compiled HTML Help (CHM) files; CVE(s): None; Summary: Threat actors have exploited CHM files to distribute malware by disguising the file as a bank transfer receipt from Polish bank PKO. The file contains obfuscated JavaScript, an ActiveX control, and a C++ downloader that fetches a payload from a malicious domain.

item.title: Behind the Clouds: Attackers Targeting Governments in Southeast Asia Implement Novel Covert C2 Communication
item.description: A novel cluster of suspicious activity, tracked as CL-STA-1020, has been targeting governmental entities in Southeast Asia. The threat actors behind this campaign have developed a previously undocumented Windows backdoor, HazyBeacon, which leverages AWS Lambda URLs as command and control (C2) infrastructure to hide in plain sight.

item.title: Louis Vuitton Suffers Data Breach—Customer Information Stolen
item.description: The article reports on a cyber-attack targeting Louis Vuitton's UK operations, resulting in unauthorized access to customer data. This incident is part of a broader trend of retail breaches affecting major brands, including Marks & Spencer, the Co-op, and Harrods. Four arrests were made in connection with these attacks, highlighting the growing threat posed by cyber-criminals to retail operations.

item.title: RenderShock 0-Click Exploit Executes Payloads Silently via Background Process
item.description: The article discusses a new class of cyberattack called RenderShock that can compromise enterprise systems without requiring user interaction. It exploits passive execution surfaces such as file preview panes, document indexing services, antivirus scanners, and cloud synchronization tools that automatically process files.

item.title: Threats Actors Use Sophisticated Hacking Tools to Destroy Organizations Critical Infrastructure
item.description:
Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: This article discusses the use of sophisticated cyber weapons by threat actors to breach and destroy vital infrastructure. It highlights various attacks, including Stuxnet, NotPetya, and others, that demonstrate the evolving nature of cyber warfare, its potential for widespread harm, and the need for proactive measures to mitigate risks.
(Note: There is no specific vulnerability mentioned in the article, only general descriptions of various cyber attacks and their characteristics.)

item.title: KongTuke Campaign Deploys Modified Interlock RAT Using FileFix Method Against Windows Environments
item.description: This article discusses a PHP-based remote access trojan (RAT) variant of the Interlock ransomware group's remote access trojan (RAT), which exploits compromised websites to deliver malicious payloads. The RAT demonstrates advanced execution techniques, including automated discovery and reconnaissance capabilities, and supports versatile execution capabilities such as downloading and running EXE or DLL files.

item.title: CBI Shuts Down £390K U.K. Tech Support Scam, Arrests Key Operatives in Noida Call Center
item.description: A transnational cybercrime syndicate, which targeted citizens of Australia and the United Kingdom with tech support scams, has been dismantled by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) as part of Operation Chakra V. The syndicate, which masqueraded as technical support staff of reputed multinational companies like Microsoft, is estimated to have led to losses worth over £390,000 in the UK alone.

item.title: Grok-4 Jailbroken Using Echo Chamber and Crescendo Exploit Combo
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Grok-4 (AI language model); CVE(s): None; Summary: Researchers successfully demonstrated a jailbreak attack against Grok-4 by combining the Echo Chamber and Crescendo exploit techniques. The attack bypasses safety mechanisms by manipulating the AI model's conversational context, achieving a 67% success rate in extracting harmful content prompts.

item.title: eSIM Vulnerability in Kigen's eUICC Cards Exposes Billions of IoT Devices to Malicious Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Kigen eUICC card; CVE(s): None; Summary: The Kigen eUICC card has a vulnerability that allows an attacker to install non-verified, potentially malicious applets. Successful exploitation requires physical access to the target chip and publicly known keys. This could enable the extraction of the identity certificate, download arbitrary profiles from MNOs in cleartext, access MNO secrets, and tamper with profiles without being flagged by MNO.

item.title: WinRAR 0‑Day Exploit Listed for $80K on Dark Web Forum
item.description: Vulnerable Product: WinRAR; CVE(s): None; Summary: A zero-day exploit targeting WinRAR has been discovered, affecting both latest and earlier versions of the software. The remote code execution vulnerability enables attackers to execute arbitrary code on target systems through specially crafted archive files, making it a significant concern for millions of users worldwide.

item.title: Windows 10 KB5062554 update breaks emoji panel search feature
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Windows 10; CVE(s): None; Summary: The search feature for the Windows 10 emoji panel is broken after installing the KB5062554 cumulative update, making it impossible to look up emojis by name or keyword.

item.title: Google Gemini flaw hijacks email summaries for phishing
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Gemini for Workspace; CVE(s): None; Summary: The vulnerability allows attackers to generate email summaries that appear legitimate but include malicious instructions or warnings directing users to phishing sites without using attachments or direct links. Attackers can hide the malicious instruction in the body text at the end of the message using HTML and CSS, which will not be rendered in Gmail.
